sp.p: Upon my life I go with an aking heart, for ſhould I be embaraſs'd with a confounded accident as I was at the laſt Ball, concerning that damn'd China Jar, I do not believe I ſhould be able to ſuſtain it. Pox on't, I've renounc'd back Capers ever ſince. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So, now for my Miſtriſs and my Father, methinks I am a very pretty fellow; certainly this old fellow wont have the heart to turn me out of doors, and diſgrace a Gentleman in his new Cloaths. But plague of his Country breeding, he'll ſwear I ſtole them, or at leaſt come to ſteal money of him to pay for them, and then ſans ceremony out goes the Reprobate Son, if not toſt in a Blanket; and egad if he does, I have often promis'd the Widdow, I'll marry her, make the Houſe my own, and turn him out in the dead of a damn'd thundring Rainy Night, and nothing but Lightning to guide him to another Lodging; or deliver him to the Watch for a Houſe-breaker; and there's trick for tricks. What a Pox is it to him. Ha, what's here Fiddles? [Flouriſh Muſick.

Gad, I believe they are married to day; that's well, the Devils in him if he be'nt civil at ſuch a time. Well, ſince I muſt have a pluck at the Golden Fruit, I muſt venture waking the Old Dragon. [Knocks, enter a Boy.
Is Sir William Wealthy within Sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but there's a great deal of Company, I believe he's not to be ſpoke with.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What means the Muſick I heard, is his Son married?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis a Ball.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Well Sir, I know them all, if you pleaſe to ſhew me up—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, they are all in Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So much the better; canſt thou lend me a Maſque, here's a Crown for thee good Lad.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, pleaſe to walk in, I believe I can. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE a Hall.
div.stage: Diſcovers the Maſquers, Wealthy, Shamtown, Littlegad, Maria, Sophia, Spruce, Mrs. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Methinks faith, this is a pretty Frollick, my Wiſe came in one Coach and I in another, and egad, among all this good Company, I know not which is ſhe. Ah, there's many a Jealous fool in our Change, would be hang'd before he'd truſt his Wife thus, for fear of being a Cuckold, forſooth: However, I'll look out for her, ſure this is ſhe, pray Madam, What is your inclination by your Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: This muſt be my Husband, by that ingenious fancy; he would be an Alderman I find; if he were Knighted 'twould be well enough, for I would be a Lady, ride in an Aldermans great Iron-workt ratling guilt Coach, and laugh at every body on foot.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Which of theſe three's Sophia? I can't gueſs but that in the Nuns Habit, by her Stature, muſt be Maria; on and proſper, my dreſs may plead for me. Oh my ſad heart.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Which of the Coxcombs is this? a pretty way to tell his Paſſion, and I muſt witneſs to't. Pox of all their Masking to this dumb piece of Courtſhip, and may be to my Miſtriſs. I ſhall make that heart bleed afreſh, if it aim there; and he goes right, for that I'm ſure is ſhe.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Was ever ſo ridiculous a ſight? this muſt be my Lover, and ſure that Jealous Spaniard muſt be Tom. Good Sir, how many hearts have you left whole, if a young Country Virgin ſhould unfortunately Love you? Or is your Miſtriſs Cruel, you look ſo pale on it?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Ah! Fair one! Let this Emblem of grief ſpeak what I dare but think.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Madam, the man's in Love, can you not gueſs.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Good, churliſh Sir, who are you? And why in this Spaniſh Habit.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p:
It ſuits my temper beſt, Madam; I hate ridiculous Fops that change their faſhions, to Court their Miſtreſs, in variety: I am ſtill the ſame, conſtant and ever loving; but if provok'd, as Jealous as Uſurpers. I'de ſtab more hearts than Cupid has of his, and lay them bleeding at my Miſtriſs Feet. Nor is't unjuſt, to think the man that Loves like me beyond a man, ſhould, if once wrong'd, do things beyond
his reaſon. This Madam, whoſoe're you are's my Character, and yet there lives not ſuch a Slave as I am.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: 'Tis a good one, leſs Jealouſie tho' were better, for I would chooſe a life wholly retired from all the World, but that dear man I lov'd, where there were left no room for Jealouſie, or groundleſs fears to interrupt our Love, but live long and happy days, and dye together.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Ah, Fair one! Would the Goddeſs I adore
Speak but ſuch words, my Wounds would bleed no more.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Good bloody Bones keep off.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: Fye, Spaniard, do not over Act your Part.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: This muſt be VVealthy, i'll take a fitter time.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Cruel Devotreſs, will you rob the World of the but one ſweet Angel they have left, to add to thoſe vaſt Millions are above? Let me prevail, throw off this Garb of ſorrow; ſhine out the Glorious Princeſs of the Earth; in every Princes Court i'll ſing your Praiſe, and with my Sword immortalize your Name: The ſtubborn'ſt Knight alive ſhall own your Beauty, Tranſcendent o're the Miſtriſs of his heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Vanity! Be gone, you Court that Honour which your Sword muſt win, more than the Miſtriſs you pretend to fight for; and I have bid adieu to all the World.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: That Nun muſt be Maria, and ſhe, i'll ſwear, belys her inclinations; that Villain VVealthy knows it. That Phantaſtick thing muſt be Mr. Shamtown, but which of them is VVealthy, which Mr. Littlegad, I cannot gueſs; that muſt be Spruce, but where is Old Sir William?

div.stage: Enter Sir William like a Huntſman.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ye, la, ho, ho, hey, Jouler, oux ther, oux hey, Ranter hey.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir William, Sir William.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who are you? what my little eyes, little Noſe, little mouth. What a Pox a Nun, is that thy Choice then, i'll build Churches.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: How came it your Dogs are not in Maſquerade too?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Pox is here with all theſe bloody hearts? Oux, oux, there, ye la ho.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: I wonder a man of your years ſhould Hunt in Ladies Chambers.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ye la ho oux, there oux too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He may follow the ſcent, but can never keep up with his Game.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, all upon me, nay then, take off your Dogs.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What the Devil's the meaning of this, are they all mad, Nuns, Aldermen, Huntſmen, Heroes, Milk-maids, Ladies? And what a Pox, the man in the Almanack? I'll mix in the Crowd, and look out for my little one.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Ladies, if you'll be pleas'd to ſeat your ſelves, here's one will entertain you with a Song.

sp.speaker: Sop. Mar. Widd.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

div.stage: SONG. Every now and then Sir William hollows and Interrupts them.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, Sir, you ſpoil the Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pox o'th' Song, there's more Muſick in this; let us Dance.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed; but what Dance?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, the Frier upon the Nun: Where's my little Nun? Who are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: My Servant, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bleſs me, who is it?—I never ſaw him before. Let us reckon our number, how many ſhould we be?

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Mind.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: One, two, three, four, five, ſix, ſeven, eight, nine.—The Devil, the Devil; this fellow will run away with half the Houſe. Ounds, Sir, who are you? If you are the Devil tell us ſo, that we may open the Doors and Windows, and give you free paſſage; it muſt needs be the Devil, I have heard of ſuch a buſineſs. Ay, ay, 'tis the Devil.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: No Sir, I am no Devil, but your Son.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: You lye you Dog, you're worſe than the Devil. Thieves, Murder, Rogues, I am undone, Lock up my Doors, call a Conſtable, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Eld VVeal.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Father, for ſhame; before all this Company.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Sir William, fye, conſider.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: A Rogue, he's come to rob me; what the Devil does he here elſe?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: With your leave you do me wrong, I am neither come to beg, borrow, nor ſteal, as you may ſee; for your five hundred pounds I'am able to pay you, and then I owe you nothing but your begetting me, and may be I repent that as much as you; and ſo Sir good b'y. I came to have ask'd your bleſſing had you pleas'd.—Now will he call me back.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who's that, my Son Frank?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, yes, this is your Son Frank.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Frank, why come hither you Raſcal you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O the bleſſing of a kind Father.—Your bleſſing Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Ah, thou haſt been a Rogue Frank, but I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Then the Debt's paid.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVeal.
sp.p: But where didſt thou get this money Frank, is it all Current? Let's ſee Frank.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Brother, I am heartily glad to ſee you, I hear you are to be married. Pray which of all theſe fair Ladies will honour me with the Name of Brother?

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: This; and ſhe does indeed.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: This is her Couſin Brother.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: All lovely kindred, faith, with your leave, ſweet one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Couſin.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, I pity you.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you'll pardon this Intruſion.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: On any account but this.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Your Servant Mrs. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Ah ſmack her Mr. VVealthy.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſmack; he'll ſmack her; ah 'tis a Dog, a handſom Dog, and a ſtrong Dog. But he's a Rogue, a damn'd Rogue, I muſt look to him, he'll rob me again elſe when his money's gone.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: An extraordinary fancy this of yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: To Divert the Ladies Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: A Hero too. Mr. Littlegad you've wondrous fancy; Ladies, you were talking of a Dance, let me not hinder you.—By your leave Mr. Hero, if I beg this Lady as a Relation for my Partner.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Damn him, I ſhall miſs my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Why Sirrah, Sirrah, robbing me already, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no, Sir VVilliam, I danc'd with you in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gad a mercy Nuns fleſh, i'll creep mouſe you for this; and for that i'll ſend my Rogue Frank packing, well I'll ſit by and ſee you. Tom, Tom, to the Widdow: Strike up there, who leads?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mr. Spruce, ſure none but Mr. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Your Servant Ladies.

div.stage: Dance: All the Dance Sir William ſits upon the ground, and every time Maria comes by him, catches at her Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: This muſt be the time.
sp.stage: Offers to ſlip a Note into Sophia's hand, ſhe ſtrikes it down, Sir William ſnatches it up and looks on it.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: What Inſolence is this.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Death and Hell.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Treaſon Tom, Treaſon! Ounds, a Plot upon your Miſtriſs; a Plague of theſe bleeding Hearts.

div.stage: [Dance breaks off, Eldeſt Wealthy takes the Note.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: Do you own this? [To Shamtown.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: What if I did Sir?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I'de pay the Poſtage. [Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: God a mercy Tom: Sir, you are a Son of a Whore; well ſaid Tom. [All ſhriek and run out but the VViddow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: For Heav'ns ſake, Gentlemen, conſider where you are; you have frighted all the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Damn you, ſpeak Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p:
What ſaid he Frank,
[Frank whiſpers him.
Very well. Madam, I beg your pardon if I have gone beyond the Rules of Civility, impute it to the ill manners of your friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes faith, Widdow, I beg your Pardon, but that fellow is a Son of a Whore, that's certain. But where's my little Nun? 'sbud, they han't run away with her too?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: They are within Sir VVilliam, but half dead with the fright.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll go comfort her, but that fellow, Widdow, is a Son of a VVhore. Let us in, let us in, a damn'd Son of a VVhore. [Exeunt Widdow and Sir VVilliam.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Behind Southampton-houſe you ſay, at ſix exactly.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So their fury tells us if it hold.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Brother, you muſt not be engag'd in this, but of that more anon. I'll not ſtay here to Night, we ſhall be prevented. Boy, call a Coach to the back door; make haſte and fetch my Cloak and other Cloaths immediately. This buſineſs gives me double ſatisfaction. Pardon me, dear Sophia, for the mean miſtruſt I had of thee, and if this inſolence go unrewarded, debar me of the bleſſing of thy Love; come Frank.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Gad a mercy Tom; now if this ſurly Country fellow ſhould give this Beau a curſt uncouth thruſt in the Guts, 'twill diſgrace his Shape moſt damnably. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, ſpeaking as he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gads me, Tom, Tom, your Miſtriſs is in a ſwound there. Tom, Tom, what a Pox is he gone? the Devil, where is he gone? Horſe, Horſe there, Ounds, Murder, where is he gone? [ſhriek within, all the women run in.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: VVhat's the matter Sir VVilliam, the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Nothing at all Child; but where are they all gone?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, they took Coach, and drove away as faſt as the Horſes could lay Legs to ground.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.p: So! [Swounds.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Look to the Lady, carry her in. [Exeunt women.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Ah me; and poor Mr. Spruce too gone?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No, my dear, I am ſafe enough, but damnably frighted.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: What, under the Table? The Devil haunt you; come out here, and run along with me to the Conſtable, and to my Lord Chief Juſtices, and the Kings Guards. Oh Lord, I ſhall have my Son Tom kill'd; kill my Son Frank no great matter, but my Son Tom kill'd would break my heart. Come along, you Cowardly, Sneaking.—Oh my Son Tom. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Fields.
div.stage: Enter Eldeſt VVealthy, and young Wealthy.

sp.speaker: E. VVeal.
sp.p: BRother, your extraordinary Generoſity has drawn you into a buſineſs, in which, of all Mankind you ought to have been the laſt I ſhould have choſen; if I would have followed the barbarous cuſtome of our Country, in making uſe of a Second, and under that abus'd phraſe bring in a Friend, as if that were ſit buſineſs to employ a real friend in: Therefore, Frank, however high your blood may work you, unleſs I am unequally oppos'd, draw not your Sword, but let me right my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p:
Faith Tom, I ſhall not much uphold that cuſtome, but as you are a Brother and a Friend, a Stranger too, in all theſe Noble
Feats, I muſt exchange a Thruſt or two to back you: beſides, I ſancy I am a Principal; for when theſe nice-chap't Grey-hounds hunt in couples, 'tis no ſingle Booty that they aim at: My pretty one was mark't for Slaughter too. And Faith Sir, he ſhall win her e're he wear her, with your good leave.

sp.speaker: E. VVeal.
sp.p: Make that appear, curſe him that bars your hand: A Miſtreſs is a glorious Cauſe to fight for. Pray Heavens the Villain be but brave enough to meet, and Rival me with equal fury, and not diſgrace the beauty of my Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Faith if he does he's ſtrangely alter'd Sir: For I have heard of him in ſeveral Quarrels, where he would truſt his Honour with a man that never yet gave him a good account of't: But ſuch a Cauſe may work a Miracle. And mine I judge juſt ſuch a noble perſon.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't: But certainly they'll come. And Brother, ſince you will be your own Maſter, I beg you be not raſh, think what you do.

sp.speaker: Jun VVeal.
sp.p: Faith Tom, and that's well thought on; ſo I will. Let me conſider, I am going now to ſight for my Miſtriſs: That is, She muſt be my Miſtriſs: Poor Soul, ſhe knows nothing of the matter yet. And I am to Fight with a Gentleman, that for ought I know, knows nothing of the matter neither. Now I know I love her with all my heart, and perhaps againſt her will. And I'd fight for her with all my heart, but ſhould ſhe love me, that's againſt her will too: Then I'de marry her with all my Soul too. But pox on't, if ſhe don't love me, that's againſt her will again; ſo the Lords will be done. I venture my Carkaſs upon an ill lay, there's an end on't. Brother, I have ſettled my Conſcience; wou'd they wou'd come.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: However Fate deſigns you Frank, your Treaſure muſt not be exhauſted upon this account; there's Fifty Guineas, put them up ſafely, they'll prove good Friends, howe're the matter goes.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What, Smart-money, Tom! Well, if I light upon a Surgeon that has any grace, a man may get a ſmall Clap cur'd into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: You'll find if I ſhould fall a hundred more in this Right Fob. Don't let thoſe Raſcals plunder me: For ſhould they lay my Money out in Perriwigs and Cravat-ſtrings 'twould grieve my Ghoſt worſe than my Death. I have order'd Horſes for us not far off. Damn 'um, the morning waſtes, what mean theſe Loyterers; prethee look out.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Stand to your Arms Tom, your Enemy draws on.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Shamtown and Mr. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, you're ſomething late in doing your ſelf Juſtice; unleſs you're ſenſible you deſerv'd the blow I gave you. But this is no place for Parley. Draw.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: By your leave, but 'tis Dear Tom; a moments Temper. Sir, ſince theſe Gentlemen know what they fight for, 'twere ſomething fit that you and I did too; for I ſuppoſe, if you dare own it, Sir, that you were charg'd with a damn'd white-powder'd Bullet-Deux, to have ſhot the other Lady, without any Report.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: I ſcorn to diſavow a paſſion, Sir, for beautiful Maria: But—

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: But your Servant Sir. Draw: Draw, both Traytors: Tom, fall on. They Fight.

lg.l: Thruſt lower Tom, my Gentleman Dances. They fall, the two Brothers upon them.
St. George I'faith Tom. Your Sword, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal
sp.p: Your Life.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I own it.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Your Sword Sir.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Take it. [Riſes.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: Then take it as my gift. Whene're I ſee you where this Quarrel aroſe, I'll take the forfeiture.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Art thou hurt Tom.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: No Frank, nor in danger of it.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: There Sir, your Sword again. The Lady's mine. Your Servant Gentlemen. You know on what conditions you live. Farewel. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Come let's be dreſt. Pox on the Ladies: We have done enough to talk of in the Coffee-houſe this month, and there's ſome comfort ſtill. I'm glad 'tis over.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, Mr. Spruce, Guards, Conſtable and VVatch.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spruce.
sp.p: Ha, who's here! 'tis they: One of them bleed.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Bloody too: Son Toms blood: Zounds Son Toms blood: Draw Dog, draw; where's my Son Tom, you Son of a Whore. Fall on, fall on.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: For Heavens ſake, Gentlemen, he's juſt there; juſt yonder unhurt: juſt gave us both our lives.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Say you ſo: Hold them faſt tho. Runs to the ſide of the Stage. So ho Tomme, Son Tomme. They move further.
My Dear Tomme. There's Frank: Was Frank hurt at all.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Pox on him, he fights every day.
Ah, my dear Son Tom: [Runs and falls upon his Neck.
Here they come, here they come: Oh my dear Son Tommy. Ah my poor Tommy.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Good Sir, how came you hither with all this Rabble and Guards about you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Brother, the Old fellow has ſeiz'd upon the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you may go, we are ſorry for this miſtake.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you may go, and the Devil go with you.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: But good Sir, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: O Pox Tom, I could not ſleep a wink—I have been at all the Slaughtering Fields I could name about the Town, at Barn-Elms, and at Putney-Common, and Chelſey-Fields, and Red-Lyon-Fields; at all the Golgatha's about the Town. And Mr. Spruce, I thank him, went along with me before it was quite Day; he's a damn'd Coward, but he's a very Honeſt Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Wealthy, my heart ak'd for you. And if my young Mr. Wealthy had been kill'd, 'twou'd have broke my Molly's Heart, ſhe has ſuch a tenderneſs for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Faith, he ſpeaks true, I dare ſwear his heart ak'd, for he ſtarted at every Buſh he came nigh; but I am glad to ſee thee my dear Tom and Frank; Frank's a good Boy too.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you for your Tenderneſs, but would not for a thouſand Worlds you had prevented us. Frank! Sir, this is your Son, my Brother and my Friend. I beg you would entertain him in your Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who, Frank? Frank's one' I always lov'd till he play'd the Rogue and Robb'd me. Frank, Frank, that was a filthy buſineſs: But no matter, I'm ſo o're-joy'd, I will give thee—let me ſee, what ſhall I give thee?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ay, wou'd I cou'd ſee it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I will give thee now, I will give thee. I will forgive thee now Frank; and there's a Gift for thee.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That all: I thank you Sir, I thought to have paid you now.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou Boy?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: O Tom, my joy to ſee thee has been ſo great, I forget to tell thee ſad News; your Miſtreſs Tom.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: O ſhe's blind by this time.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: She has cry'd her Eyes out Man. The little naughty Girl too, that never cry'd but juſt when ſhe was born, has been ſhuffling ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Now if that were for me, agad I'd cry too. No, no, it muſt be for me.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: I'll fly to comfort her, my dear Sophia.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Fly? Yes Tom you may fly; fly your Country if you pleaſe. Ounds, ſhe ſwears ſhe'll never ſee you more: You have betray'd her Honour, loſt her Reputation, undone her quite, and fixt her in the Rank of looſe-tail'd Ladies, whoſe good Name muſt be fought for, or be loſt.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Cou'd ſhe ſay this?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: More, more man; ſhe'll go into the Country too night, but if you were kill'd, ſhe ſwore ſhe'd not out-live you.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: There's love and life in that: Curſe on my Temper, what wrong could ſuch a Dog have done to me? What Honour too to fight ſo poor a Creature? Did ſhe not ſlight and ſcorn him to my face? O my Sophia, Pardon this laſt ill-natur'd Tempeſt here: Receive me with the Arms of Tenderneſs, and there becalm my Soul and thine for ever. Come, Sir Brother.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: There, there's Money for you; thank you Friends, thank you. My dear Tomme.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Thank you Sir. Exeunt all but Mr. Spruce and Jun. Weal.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Well, I'll tell her what a kindneſs you have for her: And I'll aſſure you, Mr. Wealthy, there's no Love loſt; I have heard her ſpeak as kind things of you as of any body except me, and me you know—

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O 'tis impoſſible ſhe ſhould love, that is love ſo far as to lye with any body but you.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. Wealthy, I muſt ſay I believe I have been no ſmall ſatisfaction to her ſince I marry'd her: ſhe knows when ſhe's well: I warrant you ſhe wou'd not change me for any man. I won't keep you, Sir, I'll tell her how you love her.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: So do, Mr. Spruce: You need not fear Rivals.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Now for my Prize, I think I won her fairly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Rival! ha, ha. No faith, I have not ſold Perfumes, Ribbonds, Gloves, White-waſhes, and other ſorts ſo long, but I know how to make my ſelf agreeable as well as any of my Cuſtomers: Nor have I follow'd Tunbridge and Epſom, and ſometimes Iſlington Wells ſo long, but that I know how to gain more hearts, as well as ſecure a perfect inclination, even I believe to the loathing of any other perſon. Therefore, when I am perſwaded, like my Friend Topknot, into that ridiculous Opinion of being a Cuckold; the Lord have mercy upon my Head, my Wits are far gone indeed. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: We have a ſad diſtracted Houſe: All our Servants are run after Sir William; all the Maids are crying o're their Miſtriſs.—I pity poor Sophia, but that young Devil, however ſhe ſeems mov'd with her Couſins grief, mourns her fear'd loſs of my perfidious Wretch. They muſt be gone to fight, wou'd he were kill'd.—I had rather ſee him dead than ſee him hers. She knows I love him, I'm ſure ſhe muſt; and by that Letter try'd me unprovided; knows that I met him there, but I'll watch her, and try her to the quick: Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I charge you when Sir William returns, call me immediately; let me firſt ſee him on your life; take heed be not from the way. I know the Old fool loves her, he told me ſo himſelf, and ask'd my judgment, as being a Grave Perſon fit to adviſe. I'll tell him how ſhe dotes upon his Son, and if he's ſuffer'd here he muſt not hope. And to convince him more, however the buſineſs goes, he ſhall report him dead, to try her, and if ſhe ſtands that teſt, ſhe does out-wit me. At leaſt, Sir William's Jealouſie I know will ſoon forbid the Rebrobate his Houſe. And 'tis ſome pleaſure to remove the Scene, and not be Nos'd by a Girl in my own Houſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Madam, Madam, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: What ails my Woman's Heart, ſure I can't pitty him. Well, what News?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir William and his two Sons are below: I am ſure by Sir VVilliam's talk, they have been fighting, but neither of them ſeem hurt.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Away, I'll meet with him. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Diſcovers Mrs. Sophia and Mrs. Maria in Tears, their Maids waiting on them; one comes in.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No Anſwer yet? No News?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: None Madam.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is not Sir VVilliam come neither, 'ſure 'tis almoſt Noon. They muſt have fought, and the dear raſh Man's kill'd. O Grief, O Inſupportable Misfortune. Is't not enough my Reputation's ſtain'd, my Honour queſtion'd, my Fame, that ſtood as fair as Day diſputed, but muſt my Love dye in ſo ill a Cauſe? Was't not enough I ſwore to quit him ever, puniſh his Faults with everlaſting abſence, but muſt he dye, dye, upon my Account? Dye in my Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Patience, dear Couſin, Patience, we ſhall hear better News than Death; I hope they're both together whereſoe're they are; Brothers, and Valiant both, ne're doubt their ſafety, thoſe fellows dare not look them in the Face.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is't not ſtill worſe, ingage a Family at once? Nay, I've wrong'd thee Maria, for though his Brother has been counted looſe, he looks a Noble Gentleman; and now perhaps I have robb'd thee of thy choice.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Indeed, I ſhou'd be loath to hear his Death, though he is a perfect Stranger yet to me; but would I had never ſeen him, I know not what I feel; fear of the Widdow, fear of loſing him, has made me love too ſoon, before I know whether he has the leaſt good thought of me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, I hear ſome body:

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Run to the Door immediately; ſee who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Sir William Madam, and the VViddow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She weeps; oh ſpeak, Sir VVilliam ſpeak, where's your Sons?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Sons? Son Tom's very well, but there has been the Devil to do; I have been forty mile about to find them, though Tom, he'll be with you preſently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But where's that other Son, Sir VVilliam? My heart akes.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Who, Frank?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who Pop he was always Diſobedient; there never comes better of Diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He's Dead, and I could tear her Eyes out for crying; I'll weep it all my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What mean you Sir, he is not kill'd?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: So Sir William told me; Mark, Mark, Sir William, a freſh Flood.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Then as I hope ever to dye in Peace, I'll never ſee or Wed to Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: So, ſo, Widdow, there's fine work—How ſhall we get off this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Have Patience, time enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not ſee him Child, he's juſt at the Door almoſt, how could he help it, he loves thee Child, and is ſorry he has angred you. [Exit Soph.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Whether is ſhe going? Zounds, here will be more miſchief. But how now little Eyes, what makes you cry? Look up.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Look up and Curſe ſuch a remorſleſs Father. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Now Sir be judge, is't fit that he ſtay here? if he goes, you yet might hope to win upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: No, no, ſtay, Pox on him, I'll ſend him packing: But here comes Tom. [Enter Tom.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: What News Sir? How does my angry Love? Have you inform'd her all? Will ſhe forgive?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes: I told her thou wert well. But on her Knees, ſhe vow'd ſhe'd never ſee you; have but a little patience ſhe'll forget it.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: Which way went ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: She's lock'd her ſelf into that Room within; but where's your Brother?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I left him in the Garden; he's a coming.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, he'll meet Maria; I'll go watch them.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Run, run, he follows you. [Exit. Manet, Eld. Weal. and Sir Will.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Take Heart Tom, take Heart, I warrant we bring matters about again, have but patience. Pox on this young Dog, he's met her and ſpoil'd all the Plot. To her Tom, to her; beg her Pardon, and all will be well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.l: Yes, on my knees. Nay, and ſhe muſt forgive me.
For tho' the humbleſt way my Love will chooſe,
And all the Arts to tempt good Nature uſe,
Shou'd ſhe at laſt my Penitence refuſe.
I know my ſtubborn Temper will return,
And then too late ſhe will her anger Mourn;
When I have ſeiz'd the Raſcal Author of my Pain,
Kill'd, Stab'd, Deſtroy'd, and ruin'd all again.

div.head: SCENE diſcovers Maria on a Bank, in Tears.

sp.speaker: Jun. Well.
sp.p: A Pritty Garden this; ha, whoſe that, the purchaſe of my Sword? My Love in Tears? Miſtruſt of my Sickneſs! I'll Court her in Heroicks. So, when the God of War ſets out for Fights and Ranges through the Fields in Blood and Duſt, the ſweet-ey'd Venus takes a lonely flight, and in ſome ſoft Retirement of Heaven, bemoans the vaſt Fatigues the Hero bears. So, ſo, this will do in Tears. My Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Bleſs me!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I han't waſh'd my face to Day, and ſhe takes me for Vulcan. Mars, by the Gods, come fluſht with Honour from the Bloody Field, ready to lay them all beneath your ſeet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Alive!

sp.speaker: Jun. Well.
sp.p: Yes, live to tell you how I fought; to tell you how I'd dye for my Delight, ſo that you'd let me taſt this lovely Fruit, and make live again. [Kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By Heaven no Ghoſt; true ſolid Fleſh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Such as it is Madam; 'tis blood that flutters now about my Heart, and Dances to the Muſick of your Eyes. Oh, Fair one, ſince I ſaw you Fate has been abroad, and angry Rivals threatned in the Fields, yet nought cou'd take that Object from my mind.

lg.l: I kept your lovely form ſtill in my view,
And as I fought, I look'd, and fought for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twas frankly fought; and Sir, I give welcome from your Wars, but grieve I cannot recompence your Valour.

lg.l: A Heart's a trifle to ſo great a Hero,
And that is all we Virgins can beſtow.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That and a little more is all I ask, and Virgins have them both.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But ſure you would not rob me of my All, my moſt Uncourteous Knight?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
No, I'd be thy All, thy All in All; thy All in ev'ry part.
And you ſhall have all me with all my heart. And know now I've begun, I'll fight Mankind to keep thee to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whether I give incouragement or no?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll win you as a Hero ſhould his Miſtriſs, kill Monſters, Dragons, do Herculean Labours; I hate a ſnivling, tedious, ſeven years Courtſhip, loſing our Youth and time: Put me to Action, let me convince you early of my Love, that I may neither loſe my time nor you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For a ſmall Tryal; anſwer me quick; tell me. Know I the Lady which you went to meet in the Exchange. Do you boggle? Good b'y Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Tis a Raſcally Trick; but in ſhort, it was my Lady Sly, and there's quirk for your quirk. Now, Madam, will you ſtand me a queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What made your Ladiſhip in Tears juſt now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll give you leave to gueſs it was for you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: And give me leave thus then to pay my thanks, ſince I have own'd this early kindneſs for you; you muſt expect i'll be convinc'd of yours.

lg.l: Therefore prepare, and as I find
You conſtant, I'll be kind.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Rogue, Dog, Traytor; I'll fight with him my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I ſhall be turned out of Doors, and loſe my opportunities with my dear one; gad, I've a Trick left for that ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Draw Rival draw, I—

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Good Dad put up, O Se Defendendo's a Damn'd buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Why look you now! The Rogue would murder me; I'll ſwear the Peace againſt him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Are you mad Sir VVilliam? Nay then fight it out.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir William, hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Hear you? No you Dog, but I'll hang you.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Then Sir I reſign my ſelf to you, will you yet hear me?

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Only Sir VVilliam is bewitch'd. I'll watch him if he turns him out of Doors, I have a Game to play, for I muſt plague him; and if I find he loves me, let him take me. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: Good Sir, what is't that diſorders you?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What's that to you Sir; and now I think on't, you adviſed me to it; you were the Match-maker.

sp.speaker: Jan. VVeal.
sp.p: Sir you miſtake, why wont you hear me?

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you undo my Brother; he has no thoughts of Maria.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What made him with her then?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Meer accident; he's promis'd to the Widdow, Sir, to my knowledge, tho' ſhe will not own it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How! ſhe's Rich; ſhe's a Miſerable Woman then: The Dog will undo her. Come hither Sirrah, do you make love to the Widdow here?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, here are Letters under her Hand, that would have convinc'd you as much, would you have been patient; yet ſhould ſhe ever know I own'd it Sir, 'twou'd break the Match, and ruin my Deſigns.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: This may be true, the Widdow's Jealous of him with Maria; ſo much the better, 'twill make her earneſter in my Affair. Well Sir, if ſhe be fool enough, go on, I'll keep your Counſel. [Exit Sir William.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Faith Tom, thou cam'ſt in a lucky hour, we were juſt a going to take a fair Tilt, the old Gentlemans Jealouſie was up; how fairs your Miſtriſs? When is your happy day?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: She utterly at firſt deny'd me ſeeing her, and ſo Reſents the Raſhneſs of my Quarrel, ſuch an Affront done to her Reputation, by Heav'n, I fear'd ſhe'd never pardon it. But ſo far I have proſper'd, only pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That's all the effect of love; a day or two will ſoften her again, write to her firſt; Maria will attend and plead thy cauſe.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: How goes the Cauſe with her?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: It thrives; ſhe gives me a free Stage, and if I can convince her of my Love, which muſt be done, ſhe gives me reaſonable hopes of hers, but ſwears ſhe'll try me firſt.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Succeſs to you in all: My task is hard, but I'll about it.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Never fear Tom; ſhe's born to be thy Wife: And as ſure

lg.l: As after Marriage they muſt all be Rul'd,
So Tom, before it they may all be Fool'd. Exeunt ſeverally.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: A Comfortable Being this! Snapp'd laſt Night like a Dog by a parcel of Raſcally Bailiffs, and Mew'd up here for 500 l. Loſt my Miſtriſs, loſt my Liberty, loſt my Widdow too, I fear, for I can get no anſwer of my Letter. The Devil! This muſt be malice: I owe 500 l. but to no one, and how the Devil they ſhould all agree to confound me, I can't tell. Enter Eld. Wealthy.
Tom, this is kind indeed, to viſit a Brother in affliction.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Dear Frank, I come to beg thou'lt let me know which is the beſt and readieſt way to ſerve you? What's the Action?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Five hundred Pound. I owe the Town indeed 500 l. and I believe the whole Town is the Plaintiff: Therefore the readieſt way, dear Tom, will be to ſearch the Offices, that I may know at whoſe ſuit I am here; my Father knows of it, I gueſs he's ſtrangely troubled.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Strangely indeed, for he wou'd let thee ſtarve; but I'll away and ſearch the Offices.—Be not dejected Frank, for ſhortly I ſhall have command of Money, and if no way but paying of the Debt will give you freedom, I'll lay down the Money, and thou ſhalt laugh at the Old Man's ill Nature.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Does Maria know it?

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, and pitties you extreamly, rails at my Father for his Cruelty, and ſpeaks moſt tenderly of your Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: There's ſome comfort ſtill; if I can get out no other way, tell her I'll break through the Stone Walls to thank her.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Never fear, I'll bring you News immediately. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I wonder how this Old Rogue my Father, could get two ſuch honeſt fellows for his Sons; this is a Brother. But wou'd my Widdow wou'd come, ſhe's Rich, and I'm engag'd to her already, an't 'twou'd be even a pain to be oblig'd ſo much by one who is to me a ſtranger, though my Brother. How like a Counter-Rat I look.—I'll lay me down to ſleep, and dream of Liberty.
My dear Widdow! This is kind indeed.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Good Sir, why did you ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: For the ſame Reaſon which I hope you came. Why all this Coldneſs? What have you learnt this leſſon of my Father, and come to preach, or practiſe it upon me? My Conſtancy and Love's but ill repaid, if this muſt be the time you chuſe for parting.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Conſtancy! Thou Devil!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: In Hell, Madam, you might have ſaid, but no Devil.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Yes Devil, to wrong the woman, that ne'r yet wrong'd you, but ſacrific'd my Fortunes and my Honour to make you eaſie, and maintain your Pride.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Did I e're yet diſown it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Moſt baſely in your Actions, though your Words (that natural deceit in all your Sex) flatter'd me ſtill to keep me ſtill your Fool; but I'm convinc'd; and now 'tis all the pleaſure I have left, that I came here in ſcorn, to let you know I've ſeen your baſeneſs puniſh'd. So farewell. Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Madam, though I can meet your ſcorn with ſcorn, and Periſh as indifferently as you wiſh it, you ſhall in Juſtice let me know what grounds for this; or is it a Pretence? Own it true Woman, own it, find out a Luſtier Fellow for your uſe, you've nick'd your time; laugh at your Quondam Servant, and be Damn'd.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: This wo'not do, your Pride won't carry't off, or make me think of you in any terms, but as the moſt ungrateful of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: For what? 'Sdeath, how? Be plain.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: You cannot gueſs: O Impudence!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: You Scold well, indeed Madam; but I remember a bit of a Song very proper; I'll Sing it if you pleaſe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Sing! The Devil choak him.
sp.stage:
He Sings.
Love and true Merit do ſeldom prevail.
For always you hold a wet Eel by the Tail.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Good Mr. True Merit; thou Monſter, look upon this Letter, you don't know it, though the hand be Counterfeit; a ſhallow Cheat.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.l: Then Witneſs for me all you Powers Divine,
If this be any Word, or Hand of mine.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: O Impudence!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Perdition ſeize me if I ever ſaw it.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: If I did Madam, may I never be bleſs'd with the Light of the Sun.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Curs'd Lye.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: But be ſhut up in Eternal Darkneſs in this Dungeon.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Unparellell'd Villany!

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: May I be Rooted here a Spectacle to your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Woud'ſt thou go to the Devil directly?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Nor be ever more in your good Grace.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Be Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: If I know one word of the matter; therefore, good Madam, tell me how you came by this.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: You did not write this to Mrs. Maria?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Why, did ſhe give it you?

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: What's that to you: By Heaven! I ne're thought of this: Upon my Soul it was a Trick; but by his haſte to know I find his Thoughts, yet he is better than I thought of him, and I muſt uſe him better.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Twas my pretty little Rogues Letter; dull Dog, ſhe's Jealous of me. Ah, wou'd I were out.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Shall I believe you did not write this Letter?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Shall I curſe any more?

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: How came you by it?

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: 'Twas ſent me as a Copy ſtole from you of one you, writ.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: A likely Story; and you ſoon believ'd it, to ſhake me off, juſt now ſtarving in Goal; I thank you Madam.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: No, my dear VVealthy, never, wou'd you love me.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Cou'd I have ſpoke ſuch barbarous things to you?

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: No, but you'd do worſe ſhou'd you ever leave me.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Leave you, Child! I can neither leave you, nor be with you while I am here.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: What is your Debt?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Only five hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: A good round Summ! By times he'll certainly have all I have; I'll break a right Widdows Rule for once, and Marry him, he has oſten proffer'd at it. Mr. Wealthy, the Summ's no Trifle to the beſt Eſtate; you have oft propos'd, take me and all I have, i'll give you Liberty to Night.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p:
I muſt lye to get out; agreed—but in the mean time, my
dear, 'tis no Novelty to you and I, we'll Seal this buſineſs in the other Room.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Fye, Mr. Wealthy, not till I'm all your own.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: She's been all my own theſe two years. Nay, Childiſh, why ſo unwilling?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Lord! What do you mean? Fye, in a Priſon?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: In a Palace Child, with good Company; the place indeed is homely, but the Entertainment ſhall be the heartier. Nay, come.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Lord, I'll ſwear there is no dealing with you. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Maria in Boys Cloaths, and the Gaoler.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How bears the Gentleman his Confinement Gaoler?

sp.speaker: Goal.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You know by the Bailiffs on what account he is here, they told you, I ſuppoſe; there's Money for you, when I releaſe him ask him for no Fees, he muſt go with me. There's no Company with him, is there?

sp.speaker: Goal.
sp.p: Yes, a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, in the inner Room? Run, run, run in immediately, tell him a Gentleman would ſpeak with him: No, ſtay, here he comes—how like a Rogue he looks.

div.stage: Re-enter young Wealthy and the VViddow.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant, you'll not forget; adieu. [Exit. Widdow.
I have ſeen this Youth ſomewhere; Sir, would you ſpeak with me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I come from the Gentleman my Brother, you fought with t'other day, upon a Ladies account.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am to tell you 'tis in his Power, and only his, to take this Action off, and give you Inlargement.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: In his?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wonder not Sir; you are Rivals, and he took this way, this ſurer than his Sword, to Ruine you. He had a Catalogue of all your Debts, and from each Creditor, whom he has paid, full force to lay his Action, which he'll take off upon no other Terms than a perfect Reſignation of your Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Child, you may go, I'll bring my Anſwers back my ſelf, and tell him next time I have his Sword, I'll ſpoil his neat Propoſals. Go, Lad, go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But Sir, ſhe loves him.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Therefore I'll cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She'll hate and curſe you for't.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not when he's dead Child, ſhe may like me then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But how will you get out Sir?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: What's that to thee Impertinence; prithee go tell thy Brother, I'd Periſh if I were within his Power, rather than yield him up a thought of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But why are you ſo ſtubborn, when to my Face I ſee you were ingag'd to croſs his juſt deſires?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why, how now Child, though that pretty face does plead for thee, be gone, or I ſhall uſe the ſcurvily.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You'll not Reſign her then?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll rip his heart, thine and my own too, up firſt: therefore be gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then Sir, to ſhew he does as much deſerve her as your ſelf, I have Orders here to give you Liberty; if you dare meet him behind Southampton-Houſe, within this half hour alone, where he declares no Quarter muſt be given, but one of you muſt dye upon the Spot.
sp.stage: [Takes his Sword from the Gaoler, gives him his Sword.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, this obligation's great, and i'll return it to your Brothers heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Guard your own Sir—If you pleaſe— [Points to the door.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sans Ceremony, faith Sir; from a Priſon. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Shamtown, with a black Scarf at one Door, and Mr. Littlegad at the other.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Mr. Littlegad, my Friend and Champion, how do you?

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Wholly Devoted ſtill to Mr. Shamtown, and if there be no dangerous Deaths Wound lyes beneath that Noble Eſcutheon of your Honour, I wiſh you Joy of ſuch a Manly mark; and by my faith, I could have wiſh'd the like to have ſignaliz'd my ſelf. You are for the Coffee-houſe no doubt, I'm ſorry I am engag'd: The firſt ſurprizes, the many queſtions, how, when, and with whom, where; at Southampton-houſe.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: With this ſhort Sword.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: And how bravely t'other fought you too; be ſure mark that, that adds to you, you know; then you diſarm'd him.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Accident in fight, where the brave draw their Swords, the Combat's doubtful.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: If they ask who were Seconds?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Feſter my Wound Sir, if I do you wrong; will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Damn it, how Love and Honour wrack my mind: Why for a Woman ſhould I rob my ſelf of all I fought for? Pox of Viſiting, and yet I muſt. Said each, there's no danger now to ſecond you, and yet there's real Honour to be got. But early in the morning I'll be there; farewel Sir.

lg.l: I envy you the Honour you muſt meet,
But go to lay mine at my Coelia's feet. [Exeunt ſeverally.

div.head: SCENE the Fields.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not come yet? this is the place; ſurely this Villain does deſign to Murder me, or elſe fought booty with me the laſt time. No Seconds to ſo furious a Challenge; I ſhall have my Throat Cut here in the Woods, and be Buried, like the Children in the Ballad, by the Robin Red-breaſts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant, you're as good as your word.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: That's more than your Brother dare; why is he not here? And why are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, the hurt he receiv'd in his Arm, has unexpectedly diſabled him, but he has ſent his Sword by me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Give it me Child; indeed I ſhould have took it had he come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What mean you Sir? I came to do him Juſtice, maintain his Merit, is to be preferr'd to yours.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, does he take my Miſtriſs for a Prize for Boys to Box for?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Boys Sir? Draw.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Flout not Sir, we'll try who is the ſtrongeſt.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ay, this is ſomething, you young White-liver'd Dog.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you reſign your Miſtriſs, or dye upon the Spot?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Not till I've ript thy little Guts up. Fight me but one by one.

sp.speaker: The 1ſt.
sp.p: No, thank you Sir, we can Murder you a better way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Speak, or we ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand this, and take me quick.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Smooth-face ſtand off, though thou'rt the very'ſt Raſcal I e're ſaw, methinks I'd ſave thy Life to tell my Story. Thou'ſt ſuch a lying, wheedling face, thou canſt not fail to work upon a Woman, when at this time methinks I could forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſpeak for you.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, tell her how I fought, or if I periſh, tell her how I fell; tell her how much beyond my life I lov'd her, without the leaſt ſecurity of hers. The Name, the Pride, the Honour of my Love, thou ſhalt in ſoftning Eloquence relate; and though thou art a very Villain, look as thou doſt ſpeak as thou wou'dſt for him, and win her to my Bed, or to my Grave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I muſt try him further yet, though my heart akes with love and tenderneſs. Am I ſo much oblig'd to Nature, Sir? Look then, deſpair and dye: 'Twas my own Jealouſie that drew me here, the other was a meer Pretenſion. I love Maria too above my life, and therefore dare not, at an equal hazard, expoſe my life. I follow'd her to Town, abandoning my Family and Friends: Mad with my Love, and Reſolute to win her. Tho' for your Generoſity, which thus far in a Rival I can pitty, ſince you believe I cou'd prevail for you, with looking, ſpeaking, flattering, any thing. You cannot doubt the Conqneſt, for my ſelf, yet ſtill Renounce her and I'll ſpare thy life.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll not return that Complement to you, there is no ſafety if I let you live; therefore prepare, and if thou haſt one grain of Honour left, venture me one fair thruſt among the Crowd, and I'll forgive thee yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hold, for i'll Rival you in Honour too. Be gone, there's your Reward. You'll bate the Murder. I'll thruſt my ſingle Arm in ſuch a Cauſe, and dye or elſe deſerve her. [The two Ruffians go off.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Dye or deſerve her; 'Sdeath, thou'lt win her from me. Prithee contrive ſome way we may be friends, I wou'd not nip ſuch Honour in the bud; thou art too young to think of Marrying—Gad thou ſhalt be her Page: I'll give thee leave to own thy Paſſion, Ogle thy Heart out, tell her pritty Tales, ſhe'll liſten to the Muſick of thy Voice, and give thee ſigh for ſigh. Put up thy Sword, 'Sdeath thou holds it like a Girl.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: By Heaven! and look'ſt like one—Where were my Eyes?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pox on your Eyes Sir: Damme, will you fight?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Yes, Damme, thus, thus, and thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now where's that cruel Creature upon Earth, that cou'd deny ſo Generous a Lover?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: If there be ſuch, ſhe lives among the Bears, and never came in Chriſtian Company. She never ſaid her Prayers, ſigh'd, ſhed a Tear, or play'd with Boys, or Babys, in her Life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then I am won.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: By Heav'n, and fairly too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What will you do with me now?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: E'ne Marry thee, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And beat me?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: No, live and dye with thee, by Jove. Put up thy Sword, and truſt thy Eyes alone.

lg.l: To thoſe bright Planets, I my Trophies yield;
By them thou'rt always Miſtriſs of the Field.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Spruce and his VVife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Nay, but you ſhall my dear, or I'll ſwear I wont let you go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Indeed Molly but I wont; I muſt go Child, there's no body at the Shop this Morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Nay, but conſider he's your Friend, a fine young Gentleman, and one you love:

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Very well; Madam, and what am I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Oh, thou art the ſweeteſt Creature Living, but you don't love me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, Molly, but I do, and my ſelf too; and therefore, tho' I love Mr. VVealthy as well as you do, I'll be bound for no body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Then I'm ſure you don't love him half ſo well as I do, for I'd be bound Body for Body for him. Poor Gentleman, ſo I wou'd; but you don't love him becauſe I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Not if you love him better than me, Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, very likely, as if I did not know when I was well; but you know how handſom you are, and that makes you as Proud as the Devil. This is like all the reſt, your running to Epſom and Tunbridge; ſo it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Poor Rogue, now I have vext her. Why, my dear, I always take you with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to ſhow me I don't deſerve you, to ſee a hundred Women Dancing after you, and pulling you as if they'd eat you from me.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Poor Fool, nay, I muſt confeſs they do reaze me: But how can I help all this, Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: You might ſtay at home, like an honeſt man: Wou'd I had married the uglieſt fellow in England, then I might have had him to my ſelf; or at leaſt I might have rheliſh'd another after him; but to be Marry'd as I am; I ſhall be poyſon'd one of theſe days, and then you'll be rid of me.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Nay, prethee Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Don't I ſee it; han't we a hundred Ladies for one Gentleman, that comes to our Shop?

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Gad, and that's true, and I never minded it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Lord Miſtreſs you're the happieſt Woman, ſays one; you muſt certainly have delicate Children, ſays another; pray how long have you been Married, ſays a third.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Womens talk Child: prethee Molly, I love thee, let 'em ſay what they will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Yes, I know 'tis Womens talk: Lord, ſays another, that can never be his own Hair: Bleſs me, he has delicate Teeth; how ſtrangely that French's Beard becomes ſome ſort of Faces: Nay more, I'll ſwear, I've heard them ſay they believed you were Painted, you had ſuch a delicate Complexion.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Molly, you make me ſmile; for the Devil take me, if I han't been told the ſame a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: Have you ſo? Very well, who ſhould I love better than you then? And but that you have a mind to be croſs, I have heard you ſay a thouſand times, you would do any thing to ſerve Mr. Wealthy, and yet refuſe me to bail him out of Priſon only for five hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: I tell thee Moll, I forſwore it when I was Apprentice, or I vow thou woud'ſt tempt me to Ruine my ſelf; his Father and Brother will take care of him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: But they muſt not know it; and I'm ſure if they do, we ſhall ſo oblige that Family, we ſhall get thrice as much by it.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Gad Molly do not tempt me; I love you ſo, I ſhall play the Fool, i'll run away from you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: I'll ſwear i'll follow you to the Change.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Wife keep the Houſe, remember your Lord commands you; I muſt be gone. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p:
And i'll be with you, for my dear VVealthy muſt be freed to Night; 'tis a great bleſſing to know a Husbands blind ſide; what a
good humour he's run away with for my praiſing his Beauty. Bleſs me! how unreaſonably we are accus'd for Cuckolding our Husbands, when certainly, either by Vanity, Folly, Pride, or ill Nature, they draw it upon themſelves, and yet they have the impudence to believe we muſt love all theſe faults, honour all theſe faults, and obey all theſe faults, that obeys the Devil, and yet without this, we are the Vipers that defile your Beds, Plant Hieroglyphick Figures on their Heads, when alas,

lg.l: No Woman does her Lawful Prince dethrone,
But you're ſo Proud you will ſo Rule alone;
We muſt be Slaves, or Cuckold ev'ry one.
If therefore you will not this Crime repent,
And we muſt ſtill obey your Government,
Exalted be your Horns, by my Conſent. Exit.

div.head: SOPHIA alone.
div.stage: Enter Elder Wealthy; ſhe is going off.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, ſtay and hear me firſt; why ſo unjuſt? Will you not let me plead in ſuch a Cauſe, where Love and Life, my Heaven to come, and here, which all's at ſtake?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What wou'd you Plead for, Sir? Have I not pardon'd you at the firſt word? Even in the midſt of Tears, believing your offence the effect of Love? And yet you will not grant me one Requeſt.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Not grant it: What Madam?

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.p: Me to my ſelf; you grudge me ſure my Grief, or elſe have very little of your own, that can at this time covet Company.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.l: Why, Madam, am I your averſion grown?
So alter'd in a day! What have I done?
sp.p: That Tears and Pray'rs, Pity and Love in you, (which once I did expect) cannot wipe off▪

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Bleſs me! that you can ask what you have done: Are you as Mercileſs as your Father, Sir? Pray give me way, you'd make me hate you, to ſee you Maſter of no more Compaſſion; pray give me way.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: Not till you're torn from me. Dear Madam, do but hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No, you've already made me break my Oath, which was ſo ſtrict, never to have ſeen you more; I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Dear Tom; what, flying of him, Madam?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Alive! Bleſt be my Eyes, bleſt be the day, and be for ever bleſt thou beſt of Men.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: What means this Extaſie?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Thy Father told me he was kill'd.; kill'd in thy Quarrel, upon my account. Or think you I cou'd e're have parted with you, but Tears of Joy flow on ſo faſt upon me, I cannot ſpeak the fulneſs of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: By Heaven, nor I, but thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My dear Couſin, let me but recover the fright you put me in. Dear Couſin and Sir, I beg your Pardons, for indeed I might have prevented this miſtake, but that my head ran too much upon this Gentleman; for in ſhort, the Report of it at firſt, was a Plot of the Old Fool your Father, Sir, and that Exquiſite Hypocrite my Lady Sly: For as I went down into the Garden, as he has the Impudence ſince to believe, to lament his loſs, I met this living thing there, who has ſince, upon ſome ſmall tryals of his Faith, own'd his Intrigue with the Widdow, confeſs'd himſelf a Rogue, and I have forgiven him.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Surely, your Ladiſhip wou'd ſumm up an Evidence well: But Madam, ſhou'd I begin the Story, which ſhortly you will hear, how like a Rogue ſhe has us'd me, how like a Gaol-Bird ſhe has treated me, and all, as ſhe terms it, for a ſmall tryal of my Faith. You wou'd wonder how I cou'd ever forgive her, yet, like a good natur'd fool, I have done it, and ſhe has the Grace to thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: And muſt we wiſh you Joy, Frank? You play ſure.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Faith, Tom, I'm in a Whimſical Dilemma, for I have oft forſwore the Marriage-knot, and yet it is ſome way we muſt be joyn'd, for we have made an Oath we'll never part.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſad Truth; but yet Mr. Wealthy, who knows, a good Example may prevail upon the Churl.

sp.speaker: Jun Weal.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Then Tom, I Challenge you; firſt, to joyn with us in a Plot we have laid, for the two Fools, my Father and the Widdow; next, you muſt meet no Denials. Now, Madam, with your fair Lady in your hand to morrow, at the dread hour which we call Canonical. Whereas you came into the World before me, ſo quit it, Sir; dye to your Lady firſt, and though my heart akes even to think upon it, ſince this young Niggard will be paid her price before ſhe parts with any of her Goods, let the black fellow thunder in my Ears.

lg.l: For thee ſuch wounding Words I will indure,
No Surgeon (Child) on Earth can ever cure.

sp.speaker: Eld. Weal.
sp.p: I take your ſilence for conſent, my dear; and Frank i'll meet you; as to your Plot, we leave it wholly to you, act as you pleaſe, and we'll obey your Orders; here comes the Widdow, Frank.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Be gone every one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, muſt I truſt you with her?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Go, go, you Fool, I muſt make love a little to help the Plot; mind yours too with my Father.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll to Sir William for my part, and be with you in a minute.

div.stage: Exit all but young Wealthy. Enter to him the VViddow.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: My dear VVealthy at Liberty, and here; what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Two Miracles, my dear.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: As how, my Love?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: My Delivery and my Conſtancy; i'll ſwear I was deliver'd by Miracle; and for my Conſtancy, you may judge of that, who rail'd againſt me ſo lately without Reaſon. But Widdow, thy Generoſity has ſo prevail'd upon me, and ſo much I eſteem you my Deliverer:

lg.l: I come my new-born Freedom to reſign,
And make you Matrimonially mine.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: No, Mr. Wealthy, though I own your kindneſſes, on ſecond thoughts I dare not be ſo raſh.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why, how now Widdow, what repent your bargain?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Only for fear you ſhou'd.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ah Wealthy, thou'rt too much a Libertine to uſe a Woman well thou haſt enjoy'd; Maria, that untainted fruit, may pleaſe. A Marriage-Bed requires a Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Why Widdow, doſt thou think i'll be a Cuckold, at leaſt, to any Man but to my ſelf? Marry a Girl! No, faith Madam, I leave her to Sir William, and but that thou art an Infidel, I could tell thee ſuch a Story of my Conſtancy, ſuch a Tryal of my Faith, ſuch a Miraculous Preſervation of thy Honour, that wou'd I were choak'd if I thought I had been half ſo honeſt; you ſaw that young Gentleman that came to ſpeak with me juſt as we parted.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Yes, what then?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Only he dogg'd you thither.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Me, by whoſe Orders?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p:
He ſaid he was the Brother of my Rival; and that unleſs
I wou'd reſign Maria, I ſhou'd lye there and rot, but if I wou'd, he had orders to releaſe me.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: On this I begg'd he'd ſhow me to the door, Maria might be his Wife with all my heart; the Lady that he ſaw was my firſt choice, and for her ſake, no threatning of his Brother, I did accept my freedome at his hands.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I own 'twas more than I can e're deſerve. But why dog me, did he take me for her?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: No Child, but I took her for him.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Her ſor him! Bleſs me, Sir, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Maria, by the Gods, that Devil her ſelf, was ſole contriver of that helliſh Plot; in that diſguiſe diſcover'd our intrigues, own'd ſome ſmall kindneſs formerly for me, bid me repent my folly, and my loſs, ſwore that to morrow morning ſhe'd be Married, and ruine me for ever with my Father; then with a Curſe ſhe wiſh'd me Joy with you, and bid me hug my Monumental Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: A Curſe for her again. But my Dear Wealthy:

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: My dear Widdow.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: How can I requite you?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: We'll be married to Night.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Then with my Brother Tom, in your private little Chappel, at the end of the Hall, by ſix in the Morning; by Heav'n I'll ſtay no longer. Here comes my Father and ſhe with him, i'm ſure this Match muſt pleaſe him, and i'll ſcorn her: Beſides, I have already laid a Scene of mirth, which you muſt joyn in; Shamtown and Littlegad ſhall pay the Fiddlers; the Old Fool hates them, and will joyn in it. Be gone, i'll meet you preſently i'th' Garden, and then inform you all.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Adieu, my dear. [Exit Widdow.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: She ſmiles and winks, it thrives; Gads ſo, the Old fellow Dances as he goes: Yes, yes, you ſhall be married.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who's that? Why, Sirrah, who are you? Why, how now Frank, and my Boy Frank: And a Franky, Franky, Franky, Frank; Sirrah, down on your knees.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Down on your knees, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: And a Franky, Franky, &c.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: What the Devil ails the Old Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Sirrah, you are to be Married, I hear.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To whom, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: To the diſcreet Lady of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: To the diſcreet Lady of the Houſe; i'm glad on't you Dog.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and beg your bleſſing in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sirrah, I have bleſt you Sirrah; riſe up and ſay i've ſet you upon your Legs, Sirrah. I have, given you three hundred a year, Sirrah. Franky, you Dog, and a Franky, Franky, &c.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you, and am doubly oblig'd that you are ſo over joy'd at my good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, not altogether ſo neither, I have Joy of my own too, and Joy for other people, as time ſhall try, as old as I am: Sirrah, there's your Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, you Dog, it e'nt impoſſible, is it?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir? What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I wiſh you Joy, I was juſt going to ask the Lady Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, you ſhant ask her Bleſſing, ſhe ſhall have enow of her own to ask her Bleſſing, Sirrah; I will get upon her Body ſuch a parcel of Gray-headed Cupids, it ſhall be the Worlds Wonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, faith, Sir William, we'll do our beſt, for ſince Mr. Wealthy is ingag'd to the Widdow, and his Brother to my Couſin, I ſwear I will not be out of the Family; and let me alone to make you young again.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah, why do'nt you rejoyce to ſee your Old Dad ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I do ſo much rejoyce, that if the Lady will be rul'd by me, we'll make this the Merrieſt pair Royal of Weddings, as e're were heard of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As how, dear Mr. VVealthy; if there be any miſchief in it, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p:
I muſt own, Madam, I have an implacable malice to the two Fools, that occaſioned the miſtake between Tom and his Miſtriſs. I have prevail'd with my Siſter that ſhall be, who has writ a Note inviting them hither in a diſguiſe; Mr. Shamtown, who expects to carry off the Prize, to morrow morning, no leſs than to be Married
here, even in this Houſe: And Madam, if you'd joyn, and write to Mr. Littlegad as I told you.—

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: We'll toſs 'em in a Blanket, Fops, Fools.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Agreed, I write this minute. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Go, go, you Rogue: I ſhall ſo tickle you: Sirrah, am not I a lucky old Toad: But you don't rejoyce, Pox on you don't rejoyce at your Fathers fortune. Piſh you an't over-joy'd, for my own part Frank, it comes upon me ſo of a ſudden, I have ſuch a preturbation of Spirit, and ſuch a conſternation of joy, on my conſcience, I can hardly tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Upon my life, if the ſurprize be ſo great, you had beſt let blood.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: No, thank you Sirrah, an old fellow to be Married to a a young Woman and let blood, wou'd I had as much as when I got your Brother Tom, then I wou'd ſo rumble her, and ſo tumble her, and ſo jumble her, and ſo fumble her Frank; and a Frank, &c. But Sirrah, I'll to my Daughter-in-law, and manage her to the laſt penny for you: She's a parlous Slut, and Franky, Frank, &c. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Not ſo very cloſe, but now our Plot is ſure, I'm ſatisfied our Letters took the effect;

lg.l: The Fools bit at it rarely as I hear,
And early ſhall be welcome to the ſnare. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir William and Maria with Lights, Young Wealthy meets 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Are they come, are the Fools come?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath out with the Lights, they're juſt got into the little Chappel, their Ladies wait 'em impatiently; be ſure Sir, you do not ſpeak till you ſee 'em faſt bound, and then—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, and then my little Eyes. The Lights are carry'd off.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hiſt.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Your hand, your hand, I hear the Widdow; that's juſt where I appointed her. They ſteal off. Then enter the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: So, I ſee the Unfortunate Lovers are come, my dear.

div.stage: Enter Shamtown like a Chair-man, and another.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hiſt, they are at it: This is the Hall: This happy darkneſs doubles my Diſguiſe. Friend, did you ſee any of the Family to day?

sp.speaker: Chair-man.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I ſaw a Chair go in about half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Shamt.
sp.p:
Punctual Creature; for fear I ſhould not bring one. In the Paſſage, from the ſurther corner of the Hall, we ſhall find that Chair, and in it the Treaſure of my Soul, which we muſt carry off; ſuch are
my kind directions; and then I think I have conquer'd you Mr. Wealthy. Follow me cloſe, and now the coaſt is clear, be ſure you mind the charge. This is the only ſecret I ever kept from Littlegad: ah would he were as happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; wiſh you joy, Gentlemen, wiſh you joy; you are met with I'faith; Lights there Lights: Now for me, my Dear, Pox of their hugger mugger work: we'll be married in ſtate.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: The Devil, is this Sir William! that was juſt where Wealthy appointed me. You miſtake Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Widdow, where's my little Devil? What ho?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Coming, coming Sir William (Within.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gad they have it, Fops, Fools, Cuckolds, Rogues, didſt thou ſee 'em? Enter Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: See 'em! I think I provided well for my Maids.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come, come, I'll Maid you: Where's Frank? why Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sirrah, to your Wife, you ill-natur'd Dog, this was your contrivance. Where's Tom?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Juſt coming Sir, our turn's next: Where's this Parſon; if he be not out of breath, he may do our work too.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pox on him, and his ſneaking bit of Wax Candle; I could hardly diſcern a Man from a Poſt; and the two Sluts ſtood with their backs to us.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I ſwear Mr. Wealthy, you're an unmerciful man; I am ſorry to ſee you have ſo much ill nature; what have you done with the poor Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: When they have ſerv'd our mirth a little further, we'll diſpatch em with their Ladies. Pox where's this Parſon, we'll fetch him by the Ears. Exit Sir William and Young Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, Madam, I need not wiſh your Ladyſhip Joy, ſince you have made choice of a young man ſo able to give it as Mr. Wealthy; for my part, I confeſs you may wonder at this Match, but upon my word, Madam, I am altogether ſatisfied with theſe poor Remains of Sir William, ſince he will put me in a way to return your many obligations upon your dear Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I underſtand her, but ſince Wealthy is mine, can laugh at her. aſide.)

Your Ladiſhip is highly obliging, and though indeed, Madam, I may ſeem to have the better of you in this buſineſs, yet I cannot tell
how wild Mr: Wealthy may prove; and at leaſt, you may live at quiet with Sir William, an old Gentleman that is tam'd to your hands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now cou'd I fall out with her in earneſt, for her impudence, though I am ſure of my Man. aſide.)
If I may be ſo bold, pray Madam, how long was handſome Mr. Wealthy an admirer of you, before he gain'd the mighty Conqueſt over you?

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: If Madam, without bluſhing I might tell you, I think too long. However, ſince to Night he muſt be mine, i'll reap that loſt years Harveſt in this Night; ſure of my bliſs, i'll ſeize my Vigorous Swain, free from the Curſe of diſappointing Age: Blind with my Love, give looſe to my deſires, and in continued Trances cheat the Night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, Impudence: By Heaven, ſhe's lying with him to my face, I can hold no longer. aſide.)
And is your Gravity come to this? Sure, Madam, you will not raviſh Mr. Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Sure, Madam, but I may, before Sir William can your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor cheated Fool.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Poor angry Girl.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, value your ſelf upon your Age, Wealthy admires it, Madam; an Old Lady, and a Caſt Widdow, muſt be Honourable.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, have you loſt your longing, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Nay then, take the Reverſe of all thy promis'd Joys, which in malicious eagerneſs you dreſt. On Wealthy's breaſt you'll find but poor ſupport; upon thy buried Honour lean thy head; Bath in the tears ſhed for that ſatal loſs; Curſe my dear VVealthy's Eyes; cry out thy own. Blind with thy miſeries, renounce the Day, and in eternal howlings waſte the Night. By Heaven, thou art betray'd, VVealthy's my Husband; Married juſt now, before thy cheated Eyes. Poor fool, thou art a witneſs to the Match, and hall Contriver of thy own Deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: So, ſo, the Rival Queens have been at it, i'faith.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Speak VVealthy, e're my heart breaks with my wrongs: Have you betray'd me? Are you ſuch a Villain?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Faith, Widdow, not to keep you in ſuſpence, on ſecond thoughts I could not be ſo raſh; therefore to ſave your Reputation ſtill, own you were in th' deſign, and laugh with us. Here comes the old Man and the Parſon; now the Plot thick'ns, or the Devils in't.

div.stage: Enter Sir William and the Parſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come my Girl, anſwer before this man of God. Wilt thou be my Lawful Wife?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As Lawſul as that Gentleman can make me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: God a mercy: Come, Sir, to work, to work.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: Indeed, and that's not very Lawful, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Pox ails the Fellow? Why, what Sir, 'tis not againſt the Law, for an Old Man to marry a young VVoman, is it?

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: No, Sir, but ſure 'tis to Marry your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: He's mad: My Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: Yes, if that Gentleman's your Son.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Good faith, Sir, even ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll hang you, i'll drown you, i'll murder you, i'll poyſon you, i'll blow you up, i'll bury you alive; i'll Cuckold you, you Dog.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: I'll hold you a Guinea on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ah, you Devil.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhould have Cuckolded you, Sir VVilliam; 'tis better as 'tis, I ſhall love now my none dear Daddy.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Come, come, be patient, Sir VVilliam, you're happy in your Sons match, though I am curſt; and though I burſt muſt bear it.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: My Son, he's a Son of a Whore, i'll prove it, and i'll fight him.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Hark you Sir, if I am not your Son, it follows naturally you're not my Father: And gad, Sir, if you abuſe my Mother, I ſhall—

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Murder me: Very well, i'll have you hang'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Think better, Sir VVilliam: How could you think that I, with that diſparity of years, could ever love you? I do love your Son, and in your Son love you.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Come, you're a baggage. [Shakes his Head at her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm your Daughter, Sir VVilliam; i'll be tender of you.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
