sp.p: I'm your Son, and Dutiful: i'll renounce the follies of the Town; i've taſted them, and weigh them all at this. VVe will forſake this hole of Sin and Sea-coal, and make you merry in a better Air. Come Spouſe. Your bleſſing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Pox take him, he talks as if he had ſome Grace; he made a long Speech too without ſwearing, but I can't ſay Amen to it.

sp.speaker: VVidd.
sp.p: Indeed Sir William, I think you're Happy, if you knew when.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Zoons, but I've loſt a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no, Sir William, if we had been married, you'd have made no more on't.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: There's your Obligation of five hundred pound to me, and truly, I think, Wiſely ſav'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Five hundred pound on ſecond thoughts is a round ſumm: Hum! you're a Rogue; but riſe, riſe, and take my bleſſing, ſince I can't help it. But pox on't, where's Tom? Has no body ſtole his Wife? And where are theſe fellows, that I may ſee if any thing can make me laugh?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: O Sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: What a Pox, it was not you and your Brother Tom I ſaw Marry'd, was it?

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Even ſo, faith Sir; but here comes our Fortune-Hunters:

div.stage: Enter Mr. Shamtown as a Chair-man, bringing in Mr. Littlegad in Womens Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hey day, what's here? Who's in this Chair? Another damn'd Plot.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Set down the Chair, friends; who would you ſpeak with, ha?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: We were call'd Sir, to carry this Lady; ſhe lives in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: Ha! Shou'd not I know that Face: Mr. Shamtown. Indeed, I always miſtruſted your Shapes, but never yet really knew you were a Chair-man. This, I ſuppoſe, is a Plot for my Brothers Lady; pray Heaven it be not her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: So, ſo, more Plots here; Tom ſhall deal with you.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beg you would not Murder me; and Madam, I hope you'll ſtand to your Note, and own me, and my love.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Ay, me, i'm undone, and ſhall be laugh'd to Death.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, who is this? Betray'd, oh Hell and the Devil; where ſhall I run?

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Hey day; what, here and there too? Tom, you're obliged to this Gentleman, he only came to ſteal your Lady.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: I ſhan't be backward in my thanks.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I ſhall be kick'd to Death.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: But, who are you? Come, unmask Lady; nay, by Heaven you muſt, pritty Mrs. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mr. Littlegad.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Two Fools well met, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Littleg.
sp.p: Upon my Faith, I meant it purely for your diverſion; pray Pardon me. I wou'd give a hundred Pound for a Whirlwind to remove me.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVeal.
sp.p: Sir, this is a baſe return for giving you your life; but here, call up my Footmen.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Gentlemen, do not miſtake, I am a Gentleman, and ſince I am betray'd into your Houſe defenceleſs, which was cruel of the Ladies, I beg I may be ſafe, when next I am in my Primitive Equipments.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: What, Sir, without a Shirt?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'll give your Brother ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: Shut up the Doors: Poor Fool, he Pardons any thing he ſcorns, and you ſhall ſhare the Graces. And Gentlemen, if you lov'd theſe Ladies, you cannot but ſtay Dinner, and after Dance at their Weddings, I am ſure, Mr. Spruce.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Spruce and Mrs. Spruce.
sp.p: Name but a Dance, and up ſtarts Mr. Spruce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Mr. VVealthy, I am glad you are inlarg'd; and faith; Sir, I came only to have ſerv'd you.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: I muſt thank your Lady for that, I preſume.

sp.speaker: Mr. Spr.
sp.p: Gad, ſhe loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Spr.
sp.p: I can't deny't, indeed, Mr. VVealthy, though before my Husbands face.

sp.speaker: Jun. VVeal.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Frank, I begin to love you already. Sirrah, you are a lucky Dog, make much of her and I forgive you: and God bleſs you all four.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Fairly ſpoken, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Jun. Weal.
sp.p: We'll deſerve it; but come, I have provided an Entertainment. A Dance.

lg.l: Come Gentlemen, you are the only dejected here, but bear up:
And don't too much the Accident Regret,
For two, by two, we're all but Fools well met.
WHat would our Author give, you'ld go away
Half ſo well pleas'd as you came here to day.
That he meant well is all he has to plead;
Faith then be kind, and let his Play ſucceed,
And take for once the good Will for the Deed.
He don't preſume to juſtify his Play,
Vouch it for good, or if you lik't you may.
A humbler way for your good word he takes;
You're welcom, would 'twere better for your ſakes,
Therefore to damn him were very hard;
Two Fools well met's the Play, and in a word,
Forgive him, for he owns himſelf the third.
HOw ſhall I my Rivals meet?
They are too Mighty, Rich and Great:
How can I my Celia win,
A Shepheard I, and ſhe Divine?
Or how can ſuch a VVorld of Charms
Be Circled in theſe humble Arms?
Ah Celia, If the Man that Loves thee moſt
Cannot deſerve thee by it, I am loſt.
I am loſt, I am loſt, Ah Celia, &c.
Propoſe me Wonders for my Task,
To be thy Slave is all I ask, is all I ask, &c.
The Rich may afterwards Ropine,
They would have thee; I would be thine:
Nor ſcorn me that I am not great,
Since then canſt with a Smile create.
Let not, Oh let not then the Man be loſt,
For what a Smile can give, who loves thee moſt.
Let not, Oh let not then the Man be loſt; &c.
MY Amarillis ſcorns the Man
That does her Eyes adore;
Though I immortaliz'd her Name,
And Sainted her with Power:
But now the Goddeſs to that height is grown,
Sh'as quite forgot 'twas I that made her One.
Sh'as quite forgot, &c.

div.head: Books Newly Printed for James Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-Yard.
div.p: A Congratulatory Poem on His Highneſs the Prince of Orange's coming into England. By Tho. Shadwell.
A Congratulatory Poem to the Moſt Illuſtrious Queen Mary, upon Her Arrival into England. By Tho. Shadwell.
The Squire of Alſatia. A Comedy Acted by their Majeſty's Servants. Written by Tho. Shadwell.
The True Widow. A Comedy Acted by their Majeſty's Servants. Written by Tho. Shadwell.
Bury-Fair. A Comedy, Acted by Their Majeſty's Servants. Written by Tho. Shadwell.
The Forced Marriage, or, The Jealous Bridegroom; As it is Acted by His Majeſty's Servants. Written by A. Behn.
The Female Prelate: Being a Hiſtory of the Life, and Death of Pope Joan, A Tragedy; As it is Acted at the Theatre Royal.
The Wanton Fryar, or, The Iriſh Amour: A Novel in Twelves.

The Hiſtory of the Inquiſition, as it is Exerciſed at Goa; Written in French by the Ingenious Monſieur Dellon, who laboured five years under thoſe Severities, with an Account of his Deliverance; Tranſlated into Engliſh. Quarto. Price 1 s.

Some Obſervations concerning the Regulating of Elections for Parliament, found among the Earl of Shaftsbury's Papers after his Death, and now recommended to the Conſideration of this Preſent Parliament. In Quarto, price 3 d.
Quadriennium Jacobi, or the Hiſtory of the Reign of King James II. from his firſt coming to the Crown to his Deſertion.
